text:
FAIR / CARE

Image source : Consortium of European Social Science Data Archives
The CARE principles for Indigenous Data Governance (Collective benefit, Authority to control, Responsibility, and Ethics) specifically concern Indigenous data and govern the control and (re)use of such data under the principles of open science (Carroll et al.¬†2020). For instance, the Collective Benefit principle states that data ecosystems should be designed and function in ways that enable Indigenous Peoples to derive benefit from the data, e.g.¬†for improved government and citizen engagement. The CARE principles are complementary to the FAIR principles, under the motto ‚Äòbe FAIR and CARE‚Äô (Carroll et al.¬†2020).

Click ‚ÄúCreate Project‚Äù

title: Organize, Clean & Enrich Data
text:
Step 2: Clean the ‚ÄúName‚Äù Column
Remove extra whitespace:

Click dropdown on ‚ÄúName‚Äù column
Select: Edit cells ‚Üí Common transforms ‚Üí Trim leading and trailing whitespace

Standardize capitalization:

Same menu: Common transforms ‚Üí To titlecase

title: Organize, Clean & Enrich Data
text:
Step 3: Find Duplicates in ‚ÄúEmail‚Äù

Click dropdown on ‚ÄúEmail‚Äù column
Select: Facet ‚Üí Text facet
Look at the facet panel (left side)
Click on ‚ÄúSort by: count‚Äù
Duplicates appear at the top!







Tip


In a real project, you‚Äôd decide how to handle duplicates (merge, keep first, etc.)

title: Organize, Clean & Enrich Data
text:
Step 4: Standardize Dates
Transform date format:

Click dropdown on ‚ÄúDate d‚Äôinscription‚Äù column
Select: Edit cells ‚Üí Transform...
Enter expression:

value.replace("/", "-").replace(" ", "-")

Preview and click OK

title: Organize, Clean & Enrich Data
text:
Step 5: Clean ‚ÄúCountry‚Äù Column
Combine operations:

Click dropdown on ‚ÄúCountry‚Äù column
Trim whitespace (as before)
Apply titlecase (as before)

Check results with facet:

Facet ‚Üí Text facet
Verify all countries are now standardized

title: Organize, Clean & Enrich Data
text:
Step 6: Fix ‚ÄúScore‚Äù Column
Replace ‚ÄúN/A‚Äù with null:

Click dropdown on ‚ÄúScore‚Äù column
Select: Edit cells ‚Üí Transform...
Enter expression:

if(value == "N/A", null, value)

Click OK

title: Organize, Clean & Enrich Data
text:
Step 7: Export Clean Data

Click ‚ÄúExport‚Äù (top right)
Choose format: ‚ÄúComma-separated value‚Äù
Save as clean_data.csv

Don‚Äôt forget:

You can export your cleaning operations (JSON) to reuse them!
Click Undo / Redo tab ‚Üí Extract...

Comprehensive Guides & Resources

1. Stanford Libraries - Best Practices for File Naming
Excellent starting point with clear examples

Link: https://library.stanford.edu/research/data-management-services/data-best-practices/best-practices-file-naming

Backup Strategies: The 3-2-1 Rule

Understanding 3-2-1






TipThe 3-2-1 Backup Rule




3 copies of your data (original + 2 backups)
2 different media types (e.g., local drive + cloud)
1 copy off-site (cloud or physically elsewhere)

title: File Organization Tools
text:
Alternative Tools for File Organization
If you‚Äôre looking for more widely-used international tools, here are excellent alternatives:

1. WinDirStat (Windows) / Disk Inventory X (macOS)
Purpose: Visualize disk space usage


Features: - Treemap visualization of disk usage - Identify large files taking up space - File type distribution analysis - Completely free and open-source
Best for: Finding what‚Äôs eating up your storage




WinDirStat visualization




Download: - WinDirStat (Windows): https://windirstat.net/ - Disk Inventory X (macOS): http://www.derlien.com/ - Baobab (Linux): Pre-installed on most distributions



2. WinMerge (Windows) / Meld (Cross-platform)
Purpose: Compare and synchronize folders
Features: - Side-by-side folder comparison - Highlight differences between directory structures - Identify duplicate, missing, or modified files - Merge or sync folders selectively - Great for backup verification
Use cases: - Compare your working folder with your backup - Find files that changed since last backup - Identify duplicates across different locations
Download: - WinMerge (Windows): https://winmerge.org/ - Meld (Windows/macOS/Linux): https://meldmerge.org/
Documentation: - WinMerge User Manual - Meld User Guide



3. FreeFileSync
Purpose: Backup and file synchronization
Features: - Mirror, update, or two-way sync between folders - Visual comparison of source and target - Filter rules (include/exclude patterns) - Batch jobs for automated backups - Works with local drives, network shares, and cloud storage
Perfect for: - Automated backup routines - Keeping multiple copies in sync - Implementing the 3-2-1 backup rule
Download: https://freefilesync.org/
Tutorial: - FreeFileSync Beginner‚Äôs Guide - Video Tutorial



4. TreeSize Free (Windows)
Purpose: Detailed disk space analysis
Features: - Show folder sizes in Windows Explorer - Drill down to find large files - Export results to Excel - Scheduled scans
Download: https://www.jam-software.com/treesize_free



5. DupliChecker / dupeGuru
Purpose: Find and remove duplicate files
Features: - Multiple comparison modes (contents, filename, metadata) - Safe duplicate removal - Works across different folders/drives - Preview before deletion
Download: - dupeGuru (Open source, cross-platform): https://dupeguru.voltaicideas.net/ - DupliChecker (Web-based, no install): https://www.duplichecker.com/duplicate-file-remover.php
Tutorial: - dupeGuru Documentation

GREL (Google Refine Expression Language)

Understanding GREL
GREL is OpenRefine‚Äôs expression language for transformations.

Official GREL Reference

Documentation: https://openrefine.org/docs/manual/grel
All functions: Listed with examples
Use as: Cheat sheet while working



GREL Cheat Sheet
Quick reference guide:

PDF: GREL Functions Cheat Sheet



Common GREL Recipes
Curated examples:

Cleaning text:
value.trim()                    # Remove whitespace
value.toLowercase()             # Convert to lowercase
value.toTitlecase()             # Title case
value.replace("old", "new")     # Replace text
Working with dates:
value.toDate()                          # Parse date
value.toDate().toString("yyyy-MM-dd")   # Format date
Conditional logic:
if(value == "N/A", null, value)         # Replace N/A with null
if(value.length() > 10, "long", "short") # Categorize by length
Splitting text:
value.split(",")                # Split by comma
value.split(",")[0]             # Get first element

More recipes: https://github.com/OpenRefine/OpenRefine/wiki/Recipes

Troubleshooting & Tips

Common Issues






WarningFrequent Problems & Solutions



Problem: OpenRefine won‚Äôt start - Solution: Check if port 3333 is in use, restart computer
Problem: Large files crash OpenRefine - Solution: Increase memory allocation (see documentation)
Problem: Can‚Äôt undo after closing project - Solution: Export operations before closing, reimport if needed
Problem: Lost work - Solution: OpenRefine auto-saves, but export projects regularly




Performance Tips

Filter before transforming: Narrow down data first
Use facets efficiently: Close unused facets
Export regularly: Don‚Äôt rely on auto-save alone
Split large files: Process in chunks if very large

Regular Expressions in OpenRefine

Regex Resources
GREL supports regular expressions for advanced pattern matching.

Learn Regex

Interactive tutorial: https://regexone.com/
Regex tester: https://regex101.com/ (test patterns before using)
Cheat sheet: https://www.rexegg.com/regex-quickstart.html



Regex in OpenRefine
Common patterns:
# Match emails
value.match(/[\w.-]+@[\w.-]+\.\w+/)

# Extract numbers
value.match(/\d+/)

# Remove non-alphanumeric
value.replace(/[^a-zA-Z0-9]/, "")

# Find phone numbers (US format)
value.match(/\d{3}-\d{3}-\d{4}/)
